node.title: Global hackers tried to break into Tasmania Police accounts 800 times
node.alt: Close up of a hand typing on a keyboard in a dark room
node.description: An internal report from Tasmania'sÂ Department of Police, Fire and Emergency Management has warned the agency is vulnerable to attack from cyber criminals without extra resourcing.
node.content:
["Hackers across the globe have tried more than 800 times to break into Tasmania Police accounts, and one compromised login was found for sale on the Dark Web for less than $US20 ($27.70).", "An internal report from the Department of Police, Fire and Emergency Management (DPFEM) has warned the agency is vulnerable to attack from cyber criminals without extra resourcing.", "In addition to 844 detected attempts to access the accounts of Tasmania Police employees across just 12 months, CCTV cameras have been compromised, \"presenting a significant risk to covert operations, officers' security, and identity\", the report said.", "A section of the Tasmania Fire Service website was taken over by \"external threat actors\" without detection for more than two weeks.", "\"Like Federal Group \u2014\u00a0which was the victim of the most recent Tasmanian high-profile quadruple ransomware attack by the Darkside hacking group \u2014\u00a0DPFEM maintains vast amounts of personally identifiable and classified information,\" the report said.", "\"Unlike Federal Group, DPFEM will not be able to recover its entire business operation in under six weeks, even with external assistance, because its Information Security Program is not mature enough to determine the full extent of a system compromise and, therefore, will be required to take all its systems back to bare metal to ensure environmental integrity.", "The report \u2014\u00a0given to the heads of Tasmania Police and the Tasmania Fire Service \u2014\u00a0has recommended investment of an extra $550,221 per year to cover the necessary staff and training to keep the department cyber safe.", "\"The cost of not doing anything would far outweigh the cost of investment,\" the report said.", "", "
The report was given to the heads of Tasmania Police and the Tasmania Fire Service.(ABC News: David Hudspeth)
", "DPFEM deputy secretary Scott Wilson-Haffenden said the department took cybersecurity seriously, \"by having relevant safeguards and controls in place\".", "\"As part of its daily cybersecurity operations, DPFEM investigates all reports of potential account compromise and cybersecurity incidents,\" Mr Wilson-Haffenden said.", "\"To date, no reports of DPFEM accounts found for sale online have resulted in account compromise or data breach ... further, there is no evidence that any cyber security incidents within the last 12 months has resulted in data breach or loss of DPFEM data.\"", "Mr Wilson-Heffenden said DPFEM was finalising a revised information-security strategy, and used multi-factor authentication to protect accounts from compromise.", "The report, obtained by the ABC, showed two-factor authentication had been beaten on five occasions on DPFEM employees' personally-owned devices.", "Earlier this year, the ABC revealed the private details of every Tasmanian who called an ambulance were being published online, and\u00a0included the patient's address, gender and age.", "Former health minister Sarah Courtney referred the matter to police but the website's administrator voluntarily took down the page.", "Ambulance Tasmania placed a paid notice in Tasmania's newspaper to express its \"regret\" over the breach, and said it had taken action to address the concerns."]
